data.title: ModelProcessor Unit Test
data.body:
I added a unit test for `ModelProcessor` and in the process fixed a few bugs it exposed.
- Fixed `BoundingSphere.CreateFromPoints` to match XNA results.
- Fixed missing exception in `BoundingSphere.CreateFromPoints`.
- Fixed NaN bounding sphere on empty `ModelMeshPartContent`.
- Fixed `MaterialContent.GetTexture()` to not throw not found exceptions.
- Added better test for missing vertex texture coordinates.
- We no longer leak vertex color material settings to meshes without vertex colors.

The unit test now runs successfully on both XNA and MonoGame.  I hope to see this unit test expand as we fix problems with MonoGame's model processor.

data.title: MGFX hashCode
data.body:
MGFX [resubmit]
Write a hash code of the shader/effect in the Header.

File version up to 6 from 5 because the header has changed. I had to
make room for 4 more bytes.

Everything after the header (ConstantBuffers/Shaders/etc) has to be
written into a Memory Stream.
We then calculate a hash from this memory stream and write it to the
header. at the end the memory stream is written into the final stream.
This makes it possible to accept a non seekable stream (network?) but
use more memory.
The alternative would be to store the position, write a null value,
write the rest of the file and seek back to update the hash value.

*MonoGame.Framework/Utilities/Hash.cs *
A modified version of Hash.ComputeHash() that accept streams.
This is only needed if we are going to support MGFX version 5 files.

MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Effect/Effect.cs
Group header variables into a single struct (MGFXHeader).

Move code that reads the header from ReadEffect() into the new method
ReadHeader.

We now have to read the header every time inside the constructor.
(It seems that MemoryStream that's created from a byte array doesn't
involve memcopy but use the array directly...)

data.title: Monochrome Optimized DXT3 Compression For SpriteFont
data.body:
The XNA content pipeline produces DXT3 compressed textures for SpriteFont.  Comparing the results from XNA to the Nvidia Texture Compressor we can see significant artifacts using normal DXT3 compression.

In fact I've seen papers talking about monochrome optimizations for DXT.... it could be possible XNA is doing this under the hood.

We need to develop our own monochrome optimized DXT3 compression specifically for SpriteFont.

data.title: [WP8] Memory garbage at UpdateTarget
data.body:
This code block here will allocate a new `SharpDX.Direct3D11.Texture2D` on every frame.
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/GraphicsDevice.DirectX.cs#L170-L200

`UpdateTarget()`is called first time by `PlatformInitialize()` to create the `depthStencilView`. After that it's called by `SurfaceUpdateHandler.Draw()` on every frame.

What it does is: 
-Get `Texture2D` from provided `renderTargetView` (not possible to get dimension directly from `renderTargetView`).
-Check if size change. 
-Update `depthStencilView`. 

In the case of `DrawingSurfaceBackgroundGrid` the backbuffer never rotates (and resize is not implemented for WP8). So in that case it is save to just check for 
`(depthStencilView==null)` and exit early.

For a more complete solution I assumed that the `renderTargetView` will change when the `DrawingSurfaceBackgroundGrid`  is resized. So I could set a `isRenderTargetView` before the updates and create the `Texture2D` only when its necessary.

It turns out that SharpDX provides a new `RenderTargetView` on every frame (!) which is another constant source of garbage. https://github.com/sharpdx/SharpDX/issues/451

data.title: SpriteBatch/SpriteFont rewrites from MG-SDL2
data.body:
I've been working on a new implementation of the SpriteBatch/SpriteFont classes as part of MG-SDL2's transition into FNA:

https://github.com/flibitijibibo/MonoGame/issues/246

(Most of the important info is in that issue, but MonoGame-specific info follows.)

While this doesn't cover the extensions that MonoGame added (extra Draw methods, public SpriteFont properties and structs, etc.), there might be something valuable in this work as far as accuracy is concerned, particularly for SpriteFont. For example, things like SpriteEffects are functional in the rewrite, in addition to origin/rotation:

http://flibitijibibo.com/images/spriteFontFlip.png

There are probably various little things that can be improved (pixel-perfect character placement using the cropping/kerning info may be one?), but what's keeping this from going into our mainline, primarily, is the CPU-bound performance... I describe it in a bit more detail in the issue, but the TL;DR is that the additional accuracy we provide probably shouldn't be making certain operations almost twice as slow.

I don't know how useful this will be for MonoGame as a whole, as I don't know what limitations there might be for every target (for instance, whether or not every target can use VertexBuffer/IndexBuffer), but I thought some of it might be of some use to this project as well. If it's interesting to anyone, I'd love to have some extra eyes on this!

data.title: MacOS: use common OpenGL/AL codepath (1/2)
data.body:
This PR switches MacOS from MonoMac.OpenGL/AL to the corresponding OpenTK namespaces. This allows us to use a common codepath for the WinGL/Linux/MacOS platforms, which reduces the support burden (see comments in #2782.)

Changes:
- `MonoMac.OpenGL/AL` namespaces converted to `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL` and `OpenTK.Audio.OpenAL` respectively.
- `#if MONOMAC` regions regarding API differences between MonoMac and OpenTK are eliminated.
- `MacGamePlatform` and `GameWindow` are not affected - we are still using MonoMac for platform support.
- Unit tests remain unaffected (87/166 passing on my system.)

This PR does not introduce any functional differences and should be safe to apply as-is. I'll issue a separate PR for switching `MacGamePlatform` to `OpenTKGamePlatform`, as that is much more invasive change and should be reviewed separately.
